dt: {bc}to take or drink in swallows or gulps
{bc}to take food and especially liquid food into the mouth a little at a time

et: Middle English {it}suppen{/it}, from Old English {it}sūpan, suppan{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}sūfan{/it} to drink, sip, Old English {it}sopp{/it} sop
shortdef: to take or drink in swallows or gulps
to take food and especially liquid food into the mouth a little at a time

dt: {bc}a mouthful especially of liquor or broth {bc}{sx|sip||}

dt.t: pour me just a {wi}sup{/wi} of tea

shortdef: a mouthful especially of liquor or broth : sip; also : a small quantity of liquid

et: Middle English {it}soupen, suppen{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}super{/it}, from {it}supe{/it} sop, soup {ma}{mat|soup|}{/ma}
shortdef: to make one's supper —used with on or off

dt: used as an informal greeting equivalent to "What's up?"

dt.t: [Target Bakehouse and Café] Owner and baker Savancham Nap said the secret to their success lies in the relaxed manner the bakery treats its regular customers … "When those customers come. I don't say 'hello' I say {wi}'sup{/wi} man,' we talk to them like a friend, that's what people like about us."

"We always had to drive to Compton first to pick up our suit and do our makeup in this warehouse, and then go get gas, like at the nearest gas station, dressed fully as Sunny the Clown," [Alison] Brie recalls. "People were cool about it. They were just like, {wi}'Sup{/wi} girl?' And I was like, {wi}'Sup{/wi}?'"

shortdef: —used as an informal greeting equivalent to "What's up?"
